context:
Program Name: Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas (A109)
Code: A109
Credential: Ontario College Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 1 year (2 semesters)
Starting Months: January, May, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,032.00 *
International Tuition: $17,504.00 **
Centre: Preparatory & Liberal Studies
School: Work & College Preparation
Location: St. James Campus
Fall 2023 Delivery: Semester 1, 2: Choice
Winter 2024 Delivery: Semester 1, 2: Online; Semester 1, 2: Hybrid
Program Description: Preparation for admission to various Health Sciences programs including George Brown College’s Practical Nursing (S121) diploma program. Courses include biology, chemistry, applied math, social science, human relations, communications, and general education electives.
Note: For three-year advanced diplomas or four-year degrees at the college or university level, apply to George Brown’s Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Advanced Diplomas and Degrees (A108) program.
*Domestic tuition may vary based on specific programs within this pathway.
**International tuition is subject to change.
question:
Program Name: Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Advanced Diplomas and Degrees (A108)
Code: A108
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma/Degree
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 3 years for advanced diploma, 4 years for degree (6 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $12,778.00 * per academic year
International Tuition: $39,148.00 ** per academic year
Centre: Preparatory & Liberal Studies
School: Work & College Preparation
Location: St. James Campus
Fall 2023 Delivery: Semester 1: Online; Semesters 2-6: On campus
Program Description: Preparation for admission to various Health Sciences advanced diplomas and degrees such as George Brown College’s Nursing, Paramedicine, Medical Laboratory Technology, or Kinesiology. Courses include biology, chemistry, applied math, social science, human relations, communications, and general education electives.
Note: For a one-year Ontario College certificate in Pre-Health Sciences, apply to George Brown’s Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas (A109) program.
*Domestic tuition may vary based on specific programs within this pathway.
**International tuition is subject to change.?

context:
Extracted Information:

1. George Brown College offers pre-programs, which are post-secondary certificate programs for career exploration or qualification for further study.
2. The Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas program is one of the offerings at George Brown.
3. This program provides academic foundation in mathematics and science courses and an overview of the health-care industry.
4. Upon completion, students have various options for further study, including Practical Nursing, Dental Assisting, Orthotics/Prosthetics, Medical Office Administration, and Recreation Management in Gerontology.
5. George Brown College’s Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas (A109) program helps students meet admission requirements for various college-level Health Science programs within George Brown and at other post-secondary institutions.
6. Graduates of the A109 program have access to direct pathway options, including Practical Nursing (S121), Dental Assisting (S113), Orthotic/Prosthetic Technician (S102), Office Administration – Health Services (S135), and Recreation Management in Gerontology (C152).
7. Each of these programs has limited seats reserved for A109 graduates who meet certain conditions.
question: George Brown College provides pre-programs, one of which is the Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas (A109), designed as an academic foundation in mathematics and science courses with an industry overview for students intending to pursue further studies in various health sciences fields. Upon completion, students may opt for further education in Practical Nursing (S121), Dental Assisting (S113), Orthotics/Prosthetics (S102), Medical Office Administration – Health Services (S135), and Recreation Management in Gerontology (C152). Direct pathway options are available, with reserved seats for A109 graduates who meet certain conditions.?

context:
The college offers a Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Advanced Diplomas and Degrees (A108) program for individuals interested in pursuing a three-year advanced diploma or four-year degree at the college or university level. This program has required courses such as Biology for Health Sciences I & II, Chemistry for Health Sciences I & II, Communicating Across Contexts, Mathematics for Health Sciences I & II, Personal and Professional Development, Speaking with Confidence, and General Education Electives.

There are limited seats reserved in some programs for graduates from the A109 program who meet certain conditions, but admission is not guaranteed and competition can be high. The college provides a Pathway Advisor to help applicants and students with upgrading options, pre-programs, and articulation agreements, as well as facilitating the transition into further post-secondary programs.

Returning students who have been removed from this program due to academic penalties must write an appeal letter if they reapply. The program includes courses like BIOL 1051 (Biology for Health Sciences I), CHEM 1021 (Chemistry for Health Sciences I), COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication), MATH 1142 (Mathematics for Health Sciences I), PREP 1012 (Personal and Professional Development), BIOL 1061 (Biology for Health Sciences II), CHEM 1031 (Chemistry for Health Sciences II), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts), MATH 1152 (Mathematics for Health Sciences II), PREP 1025 (Speaking with Confidence), and a General Education Elective.

The School of Work and College Preparation offers a Pathway Advisor to help applicants and students, and returning students who have been removed from the program due to academic penalties must write an appeal letter if they reapply.

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Examine fundamental biological concepts, processes, and systems of the human body, including the structure, function, and properties of molecules of life, cells, tissues, and organ systems in relation to homeostasis and health.
2. Examine fundamental concepts, processes, and systems of chemistry, including matter and chemical bonding; quantities in chemical reactions; solutions and solubility; acids and bases; as well as nomenclature, structure, and properties of organic compounds in relation to health.
question:
3. Develop effective communication skills for various contexts, such as academic writing, oral presentations, and interpersonal interactions, using appropriate language, tone, and body language, to facilitate learning and personal growth.
4. Apply mathematical concepts and principles to solve problems related to biological and chemical phenomena in health sciences, utilizing critical thinking and analytical skills to analyze and interpret data.
5. Demonstrate ethical and professional behaviors by adhering to academic integrity, collaborating with peers, and communicating effectively within a diverse learning community.
6. Develop self-awareness, self-management, and resilience through personal and professional development activities, including goal setting, time management, and stress management techniques, to achieve success in further education and future careers.
7. Apply knowledge of basic biological and chemical principles to identify health issues and suggest appropriate interventions, making informed decisions based on scientific evidence and ethical considerations.?

context:
Program Information:
- The program covers topics such as the structure and properties of organic compounds, solving numeric problems related to health sciences, using science language appropriately, and developing a personal strategy for academic and career growth.
- Students are required to investigate health sciences questions using the scientific method.
- Tuition costs differ between domestic and international students: Domestic tuition is $4,032 for programs starting in Fall 2022, International tuition is $17,504 for programs starting in Fall 2023.
- Financial assistance is available through OSAP funding.
- Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and a grade 12 English credit (C or U). Mature students may need to take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade their English skills.
- College or university credits can be used for exemptions.

Costs:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,032 (Fall 2022)
- International Tuition: $17,504 (Fall 2023)
- Additional costs are listed on the website but not included in this extract.

Disclaimer: Information is subject to change without notice and should be verified by students.
question:
Title: Organic Chemistry and Health Sciences Diploma Program at Conestoga College

Description: The Organic Chemistry and Health Sciences diploma program offered at Conestoga College is designed for students who wish to gain a strong foundation in organic chemistry and its applications in various health sciences fields. This program combines theoretical knowledge with hands-on experience, enabling students to develop skills in scientific investigation, problem solving, language usage, and personal growth strategies. Students will explore the structure, properties, and behaviors of organic compounds while investigating health sciences questions using the scientific method.

Program Information:
- Topics covered include organic chemistry, mathematics for health sciences, science communication, and career planning.
- Domestic tuition is $4,032 (Fall 2022), and international tuition is $17,504 (Fall 2023). Financial assistance is available through OSAP funding.
- Applicants require an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and a grade 12 English credit (C or U). Mature students may need to take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade their English skills.
- Students may receive exemptions based on college or university credits.

Costs:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,032 (Fall 2022)
- International Tuition: $17,504 (Fall 2023)
- Additional costs vary and can be found on the program website.

Note: Information is subject to change without notice, so it's essential that students verify all details with Conestoga College directly.?

context:
* The text is about course exemptions, admission requirements for international students, special requirements for the A109 Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas program, application process for domestic and international students, and contact information for the college.
* Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits. More information can be found in the transfer guide.
* International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* The A109 Pre-Health Sciences Pathway offers a direct route to several programs at George Brown College, including Practical Nursing, Dental Assisting, Recreation Management in Gerontology, Fitness and Health Promotion, and Office Administration – Medical. Each program has specific conditions for admission.
* New requirement for Practical Nursing (S121) applicants: an online video interview.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact information for pathway advising: preparation@georgebrown.ca or 416-415-5000 x2874. For former students wishing to return, contact Christine.Kissoore@georgebrown.ca.
* More information about college and work preparation programs can be found on the George Brown College website.
* Contact George Brown College at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002 for general inquiries.
* International students can contact a recruitment representative by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
* The Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas program is taught at George Brown College's St. James Campus, located at 341 King St. E., Toronto, Ontario.
question:
Title: George Brown College - Pre-Health Sciences Pathway Information

This text provides information about the Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas program at George Brown College. It includes details on course exemptions, admission requirements for international students, special requirements for the A109 Pre-Health Sciences Pathway, application process for domestic and international students, and contact information for the college.

Course Exemptions:
- Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits. More information can be found in the transfer guide.

International Students:
- International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.

A109 Pre-Health Sciences Pathway:
- Offers a direct route to several programs at George Brown College, including Practical Nursing, Dental Assisting, Recreation Management in Gerontology, Fitness and Health Promotion, and Office Administration – Medical. Each program has specific conditions for admission.
- New requirement for Practical Nursing (S121) applicants: an online video interview.

Application Process:
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact Information:
- Pathway advising: preparation@georgebrown.ca or 416-415-5000 x2874.
- For former students wishing to return, contact Christine.Kissoore@georgebrown.ca.
- General inquiries: contact George Brown College at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
- International students can contact a recruitment representative by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.

Location:
- The Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas program is taught at George Brown College's St. James Campus, located at 341 King St. E., Toronto, Ontario.?
